metadata.title: Journal Pre-proof Conserved strategies for pathogen evasion of cGAS-STING immunity Conserved strategies for pathogen evasion of cGAS-STING immunity

abstract.text: The cGAS-STING pathway of cytosolic DNA sensing allows mammalian cells to detect 2 and respond to infection with diverse pathogens. Pathogens in turn encode numerous factors 3 that inhibit nearly all steps of cGAS-STING signal transduction. From masking of cytosolic DNA 4 ligands, to post-translational modification of cGAS and STING, and degradation of the 5 nucleotide second messenger 2′3′-cGAMP, pathogens have evolved convergent mechanisms to 6 evade cGAS-STING sensing. Here we examine pathogen inhibitors of innate immunity in the 7 context of newly discovered regulatory features controlling cellular cGAS-STING activation. 8
Comparative analysis of these strategies provides insight into mechanisms of action and 9
suggests aspects of cGAS-STING regulation and immune evasion that remain to be discovered. 10

body_text.text: The cGAS-STING pathway detects cytosolic DNA and triggers a robust immune 13 response that restricts replication of diverse pathogens. The enzyme cyclic GMP-AMP 14 synthase (cGAS) directly senses cytosolic DNA and catalyzes synthesis of the nucleotide 15 second messenger 2′3′-cGAMP [1] [2] [3] [4] [5] . 2′3′-cGAMP diffuses throughout the cell and binds to 16

Stimulator of Interferon Genes (STING), a signaling adapter which oligomerizes and traffics 17 from the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) to the ER-Golgi intermediate compartment (ERGIC), 18 where it drives downstream innate immune responses through the type I interferon and NF-κB 19 pathways to inhibit pathogen infection [6] [7] [8] [9] [10] . 20

Activation of type I interferon and inflammatory signaling by cGAS-STING during 21 infection places diverse bacterial and viral pathogens under selective pressure to disable this 22 pathway. While the genomes of DNA viruses and bacteria may serve to directly activate cGAS, 23 damage to the mitochondria during infection with RNA viruses can also trigger cGAS activation 24 through exposure of mitochondrial DNA [11] . Therefore, pathogens from divergent groups 25 encode proteins targeting cGAS, 2′3′-cGAMP, and STING to disrupt signaling. Despite the great 26 diversity of these pathogens and the effectors they employ to restrict cGAS-STING activation, 27 shared strategies can be identified which allow escape from the innate immune response 28 ( Figure 1) . 29

Within the past two years, major advances have expanded our understanding of the 30 mechanism of cGAS-STING signal transduction, providing new insight into how different viral 31 and bacterial factors restrict signaling. In particular, formation of higher-order phase-separated 32 droplets has emerged as a checkpoint for regulating cGAS activation [12] , new structures of 33 STING in complex with TBK1 have provided a mechanism for assembly of the STING 34 signalosome and activation of downstream signaling [13, 14] , and extracellular 2′3′-cGAMP 35 signaling has emerged as an entirely new facet of cGAS-STING biology [15, 16] . While other 36 J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f 4 recent reviews provide in-depth analysis of these new discoveries [17, 18] , here we focus on 37 conserved strategies utilized by different pathogens for evasion of cGAS-STING immunity. 38

Study of these strategies has provided important insight into cellular regulation of cGAS-STING 39 signaling, and likewise these pathogen immune escape factors will continue to serve as useful 40 tools to gain mechanistic insight into pathway function and regulation. In turn, our deepening In order to productively infect a target cell, viruses and intracellular bacteria utilize 47 diverse techniques to prevent activation of cGAS before they initiate replication ( Figure 2 In the event that viral DNA is exposed in the cytosol prior to replication and gene 62 expression, the nuclear-replicating herpesviruses carry immune antagonists directly within the 63 viral particle to disable DNA sensing after infection. Herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV-1) VP22 and 64 human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) UL83 are both tegument proteins which bind cGAS and block 65 downstream signaling [23, 24] . Another member of the Herpesviridae, Kaposi's sarcoma-66 associated herpesvirus (KSHV), also encodes a tegument protein that inhibits cGAS, ORF52 67 (also named KicGAS) [25] . ORF52 blocks cGAS activation through a mechanism which requires 68 both cGAS and DNA binding by ORF52. While these proteins from diverse herpesviruses 69 seemingly vary in their requirement for DNA binding activity, they share striking similarities in 70 that each is carried within the virion to bind cGAS and block immune activation after infection. 71 HCMV expresses two additional proteins which interfere with cGAS-DNA binding and formation 72 of higher-order complexes, UL31 and UL42 [26, 27] . Likewise, cytoplasmic isoforms of the KSHV 73 LANA protein have been shown to bind cGAS, and block downstream signaling [28] . Given new 74 data demonstrating that cGAS phase separates with DNA, it is tempting to speculate that some 75 or all of these proteins interfere individually or collaboratively with multivalent cGAS-DNA 76 binding, thus restricting phase separation and altering the balance of innate immune sensing in 77 favor of viral replication. 78

Pathogens also target cGAS through post-translational modification, resulting in 79 impaired 2′3′-cGAMP synthesis. A second HSV-1 tegument protein, UL37, was recently 80 Streptococcus species enzymatically cleave cyclic dinucleotide molecules. Initially, these 105 proteins were reported to cleave bacterial cyclic dinucleotides like cyclic di-AMP to avoid host 106 immune recognition, as these endogenous bacterial signaling molecules can also be sensed by 107 STING as pathogen-associated molecular patterns [10, 37, 38] . However, the Mycobacterium 108 tuberculosis CdnP enzyme exhibits activity toward host 2′3′-cGAMP as well as bacterial cyclic 109 di-AMP, indicating that it may serve a dual function in infection to prevent host recognition of 110 bacterial cyclic di-AMP as well as degradation of host 2′3′-cGAMP [39] . 111

Similarly, VACV and other related poxviruses encode a nuclease called poxvirus 112 immune nuclease (poxin) which degrades 2′3′-cGAMP in order to prevent activation of the cGAS-STING pathway [33] . Poxin is highly specific for host 2′3′-cGAMP, and deletion of poxin 114 from the viral genome resulted in attenuation of VACV in a mouse model of infection. Functional 115 poxin enzymes are also found in the genomes of insect viruses in the family Baculoviridae, and 116 moths and butterflies, which serve as hosts to these viruses [33] . The emerging role for cGAS-117 STING signaling in insects is likely to enable discovery of additional insect pathogen inhibitors of 118 pathway activation [40] [41] [42] . In mammals, no cytosolic enzymes have been discovered which 119 degrade 2′3′-cGAMP, but instead the extracellular enzyme ectonucleotide 120 pyrophosphatase/phosphodiesterase family member 1 (ENPP1) has been shown to be the 121 major source of 2′3′-cGAMP-degrading activity in mammalian tissue and plasma [43] . 122

Interestingly, avian poxviruses lack a homolog of poxin, but do encode a predicted homolog of 123 ENPP1, indicating these viruses may have obtained alternative means of degrading 2′3′-cGAMP 124 during infection [44] . Together, these results indicate that 2′3′-cGAMP degradation is a more 125 widespread mechanism for control of innate immune signaling than previously understood. 126

Given that 2′3′-cGAMP can be passed between cells through gap junctions, and infiltrate 127 nascent virions [34] [35] [36] , future study is required to understand if pathogens possess specific 128 mechanisms for blocking these unique aspects of 2′3′-cGAMP biology. Recent studies showed 129 that 2′3′-cGAMP can be exported from cells by an unknown transporter and imported into 130 immune cells through the reduced folate transporter SLC19A1 to activate an immune response 131 [15, 16] . This indicates that 2′3′-cGAMP import and export may also be important steps at which 132 viruses and bacteria interfere to gain the upper hand during infection. 133

Several viruses employ strategies to degrade STING to prevent its activation by 2′3′-136 cGAMP ( Figure 4 ). Similar to degradation of cGAS, DENV and other related flaviviruses 137 proteolytically cleave STING using the viral protease complex NS2B3, blocking induction of signaling [45, 46] and identified UL31 as a potent inhibitor of pathway activation in cells. Using biochemistry 312 and cell biology, the authors show that UL31 binds cGAS and drives its dissociation from 313 DNA to block production of 2′3′-cGAMP. • Pathogens evade cytosolic DNA sensing using divergent and overlapping strategies to target 530 cGAS, 2′3′-cGAMP, and STING 531 532
• Studies of pathogen mechanisms of cGAS-STING evasion reveal new insights into cellular 533 regulation of immune activation 534 535

Similarly, 2′3′-cGAMP can be packaged within nascent virions, driving a rapid immune 101 response upon infection of a new target cell [35,36]. FIGREF2.text: 170Certain pathogens have adapted to benefit from STING activation during infection. The 171 intracellular bacterium L. monocytogenes secretes cyclic di-AMP directly into the cytosol of an 172 infected cell, which binds and drives activation of STING[66]. Activation of STING in this 173 context appears to prevent the induction of protective immunity to Listeria. This indicates that 174Listeria, and potentially other pathogens, may strategically manipulate STING for their own 175 benefit, embracing and dysregulating signaling, rather than evading it.176 Viral factors targeting the activation of STING provide a platform to gain a greater and 177 more mechanistic understanding of this process. The details of how STING becomes activated 178 after binding to 2′3′-cGAMP in cells remain incomplete -it is unclear how oligomerization might 179 regulate STING trafficking, and likewise at what step post-translation modifications are applied 180 to STING and exactly how they regulate signaling. Many factors produced by pathogens 181 interfere with these processes, and future systematic study of those acting at different points 182 may provide increased insight into the cell biological processes underlying STING activation. 183 Further, recent STING structures in complex with TBK1 now provide a framework for structural 184 study of factors like KSHV vIRF1 and HSV-1 ICP27 which act on the STING/TBK1 signalosome 185 to prevent downstream immune activation. The details of how STING recruits other downstream 186 factors aside from TBK1 and IRF3 are still unclear, but recent work shows that the HIV-2 Vpx 187 protein can selectively inhibit STING-mediated NF-κB activation [67], providing an opportunity to 188 better understand this process. 189 Open questions and future prospects 191 In the short time since the discovery of cGAS-STING signaling, viral and bacterial factors 192 targeting nearly every step in this pathway have been identified. However, for most of these 193 factors, the specific molecular details of how these factors inhibit cGAS and STING have not 194 been determined. How do pathogen factors recognize and interact with cGAS and STING on a 195 molecular level, and how has viral targeting shaped the structure and regulation of these 196 proteins? Could viral or bacterial inhibitors of cGAS or STING make useful therapeutics for 197 treating autoimmune diseases? cGAS was recently identified as part of a large family of 198 bacterial cGAS/DncV-like nucleotidyltransferase (CD-NTase) enzymes, encompassing 199 thousands of homologs which drive immunity to phage through the action of numerous distinct 200 downstream effectors including STING-like proteins. [68-70]. Could bacteriophages share 201 strategies, or perhaps even conserved mechanisms of immune evasion with mammalian 202 viruses? Phage are known to encode anti-CRISPR nucleases to degrade a cyclic 203 oligoadenylate second-messenger for evasion of Type III CRISPR systems [71] raising the 204 question of whether these viruses might also encode enzymes functionally similar to poxin for 205 evasion of CD-NTase signaling. Intervention by pathogens has often provided important new 206insight into basic biological processes, and future studies of cGAS-STING signaling must 207 continue to harness the power of viruses and bacteria to generate answers to these questions. 208 Hornung V: cGAS produces a 2′-5′-linked cyclic dinucleotide second messenger 224 that activates STING.

TABREF0.text: ). For 48 example, viruses with a DNA genome or genome intermediate (e.g. herpesviruses, and 49 retroviruses), must prevent exposure of DNA to the cytosol, or risk activation of cGAS. These 50 viruses shield DNA from sensing within the viral capsid until it reaches the nucleus, and 51 mutations altering capsid stability regulate cytosolic DNA sensing [19,20]. 52 Another strategy to prevent or restrict cGAS activation is to target cGAS for degradation, 53 reducing levels of this sensor, and impairing 2′3′-cGAMP synthesis. This is accomplished in 54 different ways by both DNA and RNA viruses. For example, the dengue virus (DENV) protease 55 complex NS2B3 cleaves cGAS to prevent its activation by mitochondrial DNA during infection 56 [11]. The related flavivirus Zika virus (ZIKV) utilizes an indirect strategy: its NS1 protein 57 stabilizes caspase-1 leading to cGAS cleavage [21]. Another indirect strategy is utilized by DNA 58 viruses in the Poxviridae family, where the vaccinia virus (VACV) F17 protein dysregulates 59 mTOR, leading to enhanced cGAS degradation and impaired cytosolic DNA sensing late in 60

In addition, the HCMV IE86 protein promotes STING degradation in the 139 proteasome, restricting activation of downstream signaling[47]. 140Several processes, including oligomerization[13,48], palmitoylation[49,50],K63-linked  141   ubiquitination [51,52], and ER to ERGIC trafficking[53,54]  are reported to be important for 142 assembly of the STING signalosome and activation of downstream signaling. It remains unclear 143 how these different processes may regulate one another, but interestingly, a number of 144 pathogen factors interfere with one or more steps. Two RNA virus factors, Hepatitis C virus 145 NS4B, and the coronavirus HCoV-NL63 papain-like protease (PL-pro) both interfere with STING 146 oligomerization [55,56]. Interestingly, it is the deubiquitinase activity rather than the protease 147 activity of PL-pro that is required for antagonism of STING oligomer formation [56]. Several 148 other pathogen factors have been discovered which appear to interfere specifically with STING 149 ubiquitination, including the human T-lymphotrophic virus 1 Tax protein [57], and Yersinia YopJ 150 protein, which also functions as a deubiquitinase [58]. YopJ is additionally reported to block 151 STING ER to ERGIC trafficking, perhaps implying a connection between these processes [58]. 152 Several viral proteins directly target STING trafficking to the ERGIC, which requires the 153 iRhom2/TRAPβ complex [54]. The HCMV tegument protein UL82 disrupts the complex between 154 STING, iRhom2 and TRAPβ [59]. Similarly, HCMV UL42, along with its role in antagonizing 155 cGAS oligomerization, is reported to stimulate degradation of TRAPβ in order to block STING 156 trafficking [27]. Last, the bacterium Shigella flexneri encodes IpaJ which inhibits STING 157 trafficking by an indirect mechanism, targeting ARF GTPases to block traffic out of the ER [60]. 158 After assembly of STING oligomers in the ERGIC, downstream signaling factors 159 associate in order to drive antiviral and inflammatory responses. The mechanism is best 160 understood for the kinase TBK1 and transcription factor IRF3 which associate with the STING 161 C-terminal tail and become activated by trans-phosphorylation driven by assembly of multiple 162 molecules on adjacent STING monomers [13,14,61]. The KSHV vIRF1 protein blocks this 163 process, preventing association of TBK1 [62]. Mareck's disease virus is an avian oncogenic herpesvirus, and its oncoprotein Meq functions in a similar way, blocking recruitment of TBK1 to 165 STING in chicken cells [63]. Interestingly, the oncoproteins E1A and E7 from adenovirus and 166 human papillomavirus also bind and inhibit STING, however the mechanistic consequences of 167 binding have not yet been elucidated [64]. HSV-1 ICP27 functions differently, associating with 168 the active STING/TBK1 complex, and preventing IRF3 recruitment and phosphorylation to block 169 the downstream type I interferon response [65].
